Literature Review: Long-read DNA sequencing (LRS) technologies have emerged as powerful tools for genomic analysis, overcoming many limitations associated with short-read sequencing methods. These advancements have significantly enhanced our ability to study complex genomic regions, including large structural variants (SVs) and repetitive DNA sequences, which were previously challenging to analyze with short-read technologies. This literature review explores recent advances in LRS, its applications in genomic research, and the challenges that remain.One of the most significant contributions of LRS is its ability to sequence DNA fragments tens to hundreds of kilobase pairs in length. This capability has been instrumental in the analysis of large SVs, which are often implicated in genetic disorders and diseases. For instance, studies have demonstrated the utility of LRS in identifying and characterizing rare pathogenic SVs that were undetectable with short-read sequencing (Chaisson et al., 2019). Moreover, LRS has facilitated haplotypic phasing, allowing researchers to determine the parental origin of alleles and understand the impact of compound heterozygosity on disease phenotypes (Seo et al., 2020).The assembly of a complete, gapless human genome represents another milestone achieved through LRS. This accomplishment has filled critical gaps in the reference genome, including highly repetitive centromeres and homologous acrocentric short arms, which were previously intractable with short-read sequencing (Miga et al., 2020). The complete genome assembly has provided unprecedented insights into the structure and function of these regions, shedding light on their roles in chromosome stability and segregation.LRS has also enabled the discovery and characterization of repeat expansions associated with neurodegenerative and neuromuscular disorders. For example, LRS has been used to identify novel repeat expansions in genes linked to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Huntington's disease, expanding our understanding of the genetic basis of these conditions (DeJesus-Hernandez et al., 2017; Ishiura et al., 2018). Additionally, LRS has facilitated the study of epigenetic modifications, such as DNA methylation, by directly detecting these modifications without the need for bisulfite conversion (Simpson et al., 2017).Despite these advancements, several challenges remain in the field of LRS. One of the primary limitations is the higher error rate associated with LRS compared to short-read sequencing. Although recent improvements in sequencing chemistry and base-calling algorithms have reduced error rates, further optimization is needed to enhance the accuracy of LRS data (Jain et al., 2018). Another challenge is the cost and throughput of LRS, which, despite significant reductions, still lag behind those of short-read sequencing technologies. Efforts to increase the scalability and affordability of LRS are ongoing, with the aim of making it more accessible for large-scale genomic studies (Logsdon et al., 2020).In conclusion, LRS has revolutionized genomic research by enabling the analysis of complex genomic regions and providing insights into the genetic basis of diseases. The ability to sequence long DNA fragments, assemble complete genomes, and detect epigenetic modifications has opened new avenues for understanding genetic diversity and pathogenic mutations. However, challenges related to error rates, cost, and throughput must be addressed to fully realize the potential of LRS in genomic medicine.
